awd_titl_txt: Multi-scale Nanotextured Surfaces by Tribo-Electrohydrodynamic Lithography for Controlled Drug Release
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports research that creates a disruptive nanoscale manufacturing technology for rapid fabrication of multiscale nanostructures, promotes scientific progress, and advances national prosperity and health. Realization of multiscale nanostructures with existing nanofabrication methods is a challenging endeavor. For example, electron beam lithography is limited to very small scale structures, whereas nanoimprint lithography requires very elaborate master patterns. This project explores the technique of nanoscale replica molding as a rapid and inexpensive way to form intricate master nanostructures from large-area templates. The accompanying formation of surface "tribocharges" are utilized to fabricate multiscale nanostructures with sub-100 nanometer sub-structures. By this means, nanotextured surfaces having biomedical uses are possible. With elaborate plans to stimulate nanomanufacturing and bring the resulting surface-patterned biomedical devices to the people with heart-disease, this work aligns well with the nation's efforts to boost manufacturing in the U.S. and to innovate biomedical technologies. This research involves several disciplines including manufacturing, surface physics, electromagnetics, and materials science. This multi-disciplinary approach helps broaden the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in research and positively impacts engineering education.

This project enables highly controlled nanopatterning of tribocharge distribution on polymer substrates through nanoscale replica molding and provides a deeper understanding of the underlying mechanisms for generation and patterning of tribocharges. Investigations of the tribocharge's longevity, spatial stability, and nanotexture dependence are performed. The nanopatterned tribocharges are then used as the source of nanoscale-modulated electric fields for electrohydrodynamic lithography, by which 3-level hierarchical multiscale nanostructures are fabricated. The target nanostructures include nanoscale volcanoes with sub-100 nm-scale nanocraters and multiple-period nanostructure arrays. The drug release from such multiscale nanotextures made of biocompatible polymers are also studied for emerging applications such as stents for cardiac therapies. The fundamental research outcomes widen the knowledge required for the realization of multiscale nanostructures in general, eventually enabling the synthesis of new materials and structures with novel functionalities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project were to develop disruptive manufacturing technologies for the fabrication of novel multiscale nanostructures for applications in science, medicine, energy-harvesting and flexible electronics. These nanostructures have feature sizes less than 1 micrometer and require manufacturing capabilities over large areas. The state-of-the-art manufacturing method for such multiscale nanostructures is based on electron beam lithography. Although being very precise, electron beam lithography has the disadvantage of i) very high equipment cost, ii) limited access to such facilities or nanofabrication centers, and iii) the limitation to very small areas, typically less than 1 mm across, which is unsuitable for large area applications such as solar cells or lighting panels. Hence, this project has developed an alternative method for nanoscale replica molding as a rapid and inexpensive way to form intricate nanostructures on polymers from large-area templates.

 

The intellectual merit of the project is that we developed a new mode of replica molding in which a polymer mold (e.g. polycarbonate) is imprinted on a second polymer surface and then peeled off to induce an intricate pattern of surface charges, i.e. tribocharges, on the surface of the polymer. We characterized the topography of the polymer film with atomic force microscopy (AFM) and the surface charge with Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) that measures the electric potential on the surface. By combining these measurements with finite-element simulations of the molding process, we found that tribocharges preferentially form in regions where large interstitial stress occurred during the demolding step of the replica molding process.

 

For sustained utilization of the novel nanopatterned tribocharge, their stability and temporal behavior must be characterized and studied. We performed this highly challenging task through long-term, repeated probing of the tribocharge at the nanoscale spatial resolution. We performed surface characterization measurements over several days and found that the tribocharges has a component exhibiting short-time decay over several hours, and a long-time component that decayed very slowly. The fast and slow decay components of the tribocharges were generated by the tangential sliding and surface-normal separation motions applied to the material interface during the demolding action, respectively. Even after two weeks there was a stable component of the surface tribocharge that exceeded half of its initial value, that could be utilized for further experiments. The surface tribocharge can be utilized for maskless lithography where the charged polymer substrate placed in proximity to another target polymer can induce charges and patterns on the target polymer. We demonstrated this electrohydrodynamic lithography process wherein the intricate pattern of tribocharges is transferred to a test polymer substrate, forming multiscale patterns over large areas, a process that would be exceedingly difficult to achieve by traditional lithographic methods.

 

We found that our multi-physical model can relate the replica molding and tribocharging in both recessed and protruding nanotextures. The regions on the surface that experience strong interfacial friction during replica molding exhibited high surface potential and tribocharge density. The aspect ratio of the nanostructures determines the charging behavior. We performed ab-initio density functional theory simulations of the rupture of polymer chains and found pathways that show how ruptured polymer chains acquire charge.

 

In the area of broad impact, we have performed industrial outreach by collaborating with a technology start-up company with roll-to-roll manufacturing capabilities. This company provided us large area nanoscale patterned molds that lead to a joint publication, and broad impact to industrial sector. In other areas of broad impact, the project has trained two Ph.D. students and one M.S. student – all of whom have joined the microelectronics and information technology sector industries after graduation, making excellent use of the skills they acquired in this project. Three undergraduate students were trained in experimental techniques, providing training and professional development for their future careers. Findings from this project were incorporated into i) undergraduate Physics Electromagnetism courses, thereby enabling the students to understand how electric potentials are measured on the surfaces of materials, and ii) graduate and undergraduate special topics Electrical Engineering courses.  More than 12 invited talks were presented at international conferences and invited colloquia at Universities, providing dissemination to communities of interest. Six papers were published including two in very high impact journals. Two press releases were issued by College of Engineering. The project results will widen our fundamental understanding of nanoscale triboelectricity and advance the nanopatterned charge generation process for future manufacturing applications.

 


Last Modified: 11/14/2024
Modified by: Rana Biswas
